title: Acharya Prashant on Truth, Suffering, and Media Awareness
content:
# Acharya Prashant on Truth, Suffering, and Media Awareness

A profound dialogue unfolds, sparked by a question rooted in fear and admiration. A listener points to the great figures of history—Swami Vivekananda, Socrates, Bhagat Singh—who walked the path of truth and endured immense suffering and societal opposition. The underlying question is one of trepidation: "If we walk that path, won't we too face terrible opposition, just as you do?"

Acharya Prashant’s response dismantles the very premise of the fear with piercing clarity and characteristic wit. He begins not with an answer, but with a counter-question that reframes the entire narrative.

## The Observer's Delusion: Weeping for a Suffering That Never Was

**"Were they crying?"** Acharya Prashant asks.
The listener confirms, "They endured that torture and all, but they weren't crying."
**"Then why are *you* crying?"** comes the swift, disarming reply. "You are not even ready to get a scratch, and you are already crying. What is this? What do you want?"

He dissects the illusion of suffering we project onto the truth-seeker. The torture, the stones, the poison, the slander—all of that happens *externally*. It is public, visible to all. But the critical question is: **Did that suffering enter *within* them?** How do you know?

"We don't feel that it had any effect within them," he observes. "They were not seen wailing, not seen begging for forgiveness, not seen regretting—'Alas, what have I done, my plight is ruined!'—nowhere is this found. Because the suffering could not reach within them. Those outside did what they had to do. Who knows, inside they might have been blissful, joyous, playing kabaddi! How do you know?"

He paints a vivid picture of the dichotomy:
*   **The one standing before death** is in a state of *Ananda* (bliss).
*   **The one watching from afar** is trembling, shivering, saying, "Oh no, a terrible thing has happened to this poor soul!"

**"The one facing it is in joy. And the one watching from afar and shivering is saying, 'What will happen to me?' What answer can I give?"**

## The Selective Narrative: "This World is Very Cruel"

Acharya Prashant identifies the core pattern of the fearful mind: it selectively curates examples to confirm its own victimhood narrative.

**"You pick and choose only those examples where there was turmoil."** You come saying, **"This world... I tell you, this world is very cruel. It treats good people very badly."**
He laughs, **"That's why I am a bit of a rascal!"**

He challenges this curated history. "Does it happen in India? We don't know that the sages of the Upanishads were crucified on the cross. Did it happen? It didn't happen. Sometimes it happens, sometimes it doesn't. Examples exist from every direction."
*   Someone departs at 25.
*   Someone lives to 90, 100, 120. Lao Tzu, they say, was born at 84.
**"Examples are from every direction. But you will pick and choose only where this happens. I tell you, this world is very cruel."** He adds with a chuckle, **"The straight tree is cut down quickly. That's why I am the crooked finger."**

## The Real Sufferer: The One Who Bends

He delivers a fundamental truth: **"The world can do nothing. The world can only do something to the one who drools in front of the world."**

**"The ones whose names you are taking—the world can do nothing to them. Nothing.**
**And those who walk cautiously, bowing in servitude—it is them the world thrashes thoroughly."**

The problem is not the world's cruelty, but one's own readiness to be enslaved. **"The world cannot break truth. Yes, *you* are ready to be sold. Slaves have always been beaten. Why give the world the credit? Say it directly—'I am ready to be sold, that's why I am beaten.' Don't say all these things about the great souls. Poor Vivekananda? Poor Socrates?"**

## The Immortality of Truth: Socrates Never Died

He then offers a breathtaking perspective on the immortality of truth, using Socrates as the prime example.

"What is this 'poor Socrates'? *Renaissance* means rebirth. Rebirth of whom? **Socrates resurrected.** The intellectual and technological progress you see in Europe today is the very rebirth of Socrates. That was its name—Renaissance."

He narrates how, after the Dark Ages, a Roman thinker went back 2000 years to rediscover the Greek philosophers, restarting the Renaissance in Italy.
**"Poor Socrates? Socrates never died. Socrates, 2000 years after his death, came and revived Europe. So you are saying they gave Socrates suffering? Socrates does not die. Is the point coming through?"**

He extends this to Krishna from the Indian tradition. "Fools are those who think Krishna was struck by an arrow and died. Krishna died? He exists at all times, in every age, everywhere, in a time-relative form. Neither Krishna nor Arjuna has to go anywhere."

**"You cannot kill them. Give them torture, give them poison, shoot an arrow, shoot a bullet, do something, behead them. They do not die. They are such that they don't die even after dying. And we are such that we don't live even while being alive."**

Truth is as indestructible as life itself. **"Every child that is born, it is not crying for its mother. It is crying for the great Mother. It wants truth. How can truth die? As long as a single child is being born... all of them are in motion. All motion is only to reach motionlessness. As long as there is motionlessness, there is truth."**

## The Practical Toolkit: Media Literacy as Modern Spirituality

The dialogue then pivots to a deeply practical question from a youth: In today's context, bombarded by influences from teachers, seniors, and especially technology, how does one recognize who is "lofty" or truthful?

Acharya Prashant identifies this as the central spiritual challenge of our age.

**"You will have to look at two things, and it is these two we miss."** When a screen is in front and eyes are watching:
*   We don't see **who is behind the screen**.
*   We don't see **who is behind the eyes**.

**"Whenever something is being shown to you, remember it was in front of the camera, hence you saw it. Also ask: Who was behind the camera? The one who shows often does not appear in the camera. The nature of the camera is such that the owner of the camera will never be seen in it. Who is showing?"**

### The Algorithmic Consciousness

He names the modern malaise: **"Their consciousness has become algorithmic. Their consciousness itself has become what the algorithm has made."** Why? Because eyes are ancient, but this technology is new. Eyes evolved to see the immediate physical threat (a lion), not to see the manipulator behind the digital imagery.

**"So we will have to train our eyes. This is today's spirituality: To see behind the screen."**

His core instruction: **"Whenever anyone shows you anything, always ask: Who is behind this?"** And then, turn the inquiry inward. **"And when any liking, disliking, hatred, or love arises within you upon seeing it, ask that too: Who is behind *this*? Is it not the same one who is behind the camera?"**

**"Because this entire media wants only this, no? To become your very center. You are liking something. Ask yourself: Is it not that I have been taught to like this by the same one who showed me this scene?"**

**"When both the seen and the seer are under whose control? The one showing is the algorithm. We cannot change this thing. But at least let the seer not be algorithmic. We should have a choice in this."**

### The Pause Button: The Most Precious Tool

The practical method is stunningly simple: **"Learn to tear the screen. Penetrate. Someone very cunning is sitting there who does not want to come in front of the camera. Usually, puppets are placed in front of the camera."**

**"The Pause button is very important. Press pause. Pause and ask: Who is behind this? And when a big emotion starts rising within you, then again press pause and ask: Who is behind *me*?"**

He breaks it down for even a schoolchild:
1.  **Ask the basic question:** "Who made this program/movie? What is their desire, agenda, objective?"
2.  **Even if the objective is just to make money,** keep telling yourself: "He showed me whatever he showed so that his money is made."
3.  ​​**Look for the edit:** "Why was this dialogue said in *this* way and not *that* way? Many things that should have been said were not. And one very small point was over-emphasized. What is the reason?"
4.  **Question the pace:** "He is speaking very fast. Why is he not stopping? He is not stopping because he does not want you to think."

**"This is called critical engagement. Dumb reception versus critical engagement."** When the public critically engages with information, the provider also becomes cautious. "He thinks, 'If I do more cunning, I will be caught. If I lie, I will be exposed. So let me stay straight, stay truthful.'"

## Attention, Format, and Authentic Engagement

Addressing a concern about shortening attention spans, especially among students, Acharya Prashant is dismissive of the notion.

"Look, the longest tennis matches have been played in the last 5-20 years... Millions were watching for four-five hours. Where has the attention span decreased?"
"Podcasts run for four-five hours. Many run for two-three hours. This very session will have gone on for 4 hours... I don't think the attention span is so low."

The issue, he clarifies, is one of **format and engagement**, not capacity.
*   The 1-minute reel is one format—akin to ancient aphorisms (*sutras*) that conveyed gravity through brevity.
*   When you win people's hearts, they will listen for four hours. "If a Test match comes, they watch for five days. They watch, no? It depends on whether the heart is won or not."

He concludes with a poignant, humorous note on adaptation. **"If I start speaking to you in pure Sanskritized Hindi now, fifty will leave, a hundred will leave. So the language also has to be kept like that. One has to provide enjoyment. Did you enjoy or not?"**

The session ends, leaving a powerful synthesis: The path of truth is not one of fearful suffering but of indestructible joy. And the modern seeker's primary practice is to develop the penetrating vision to see behind every screen and behind every arising thought, reclaiming consciousness from the algorithm. It is a call to move from being a "dumb receiver" to a critically engaged, fearless, and truly alive human being.
